comment.author: 44124400583@N01
comment._content:
New York Times-
GIRL IN LONG SWIM TO CONEY ISLAND; Rose Pitonof, 17 Years Old, Reaches Goal After Covering Twenty-one Miles.

August 14, 1911, Monday

Miss Rose Pitonof, the seventeen-year-old swimming marvel from Dorchester, Mass., added another wonderful performance to her record yesterday when she successfully negotiated the distance between East Twenty-sixth Street, Manhattan, and Steeplechase Pier, Coney Island.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks!  We'll add some of this information in the source data and reload the description.

comment.author: 27859140@N08
comment._content: In order to appreciate female athelics, such as swimmers, I thought it was best to do alittle research on the history of first female long distance swimmer, by the name Rose Pitonof. Source: The New York Times, " Girl in Long Swim to Coney Island, Forced to Battle with Adverse Tides at Start and Finish--Girl receives Great Demonstration ". Copyright: The New York Times, August 14, 1911. Rose Pitonof, a 17 year old girl swimmier from Dorchester, Mass., she is the first girl to accomplish difficult task of long distance swimming. Her performance outclassed anything ever attempted by a girl swimmer in Easter water. Last year, she succeeded in covering the difficult course from Charlestown to Boston Light, a feat seldom accomplished by man and never before or sence by a woman. To find more information about Rose Pitonof, go to: texasswimming.blogspot.com/2008/01/rose-pitonof.html
